Overview

Get the lowdown on the foundation of the Web Skin platform, including our approach to better, faster, stronger web application development.

HTML5 doctype required

Web Skin makes use of certain HTML elements and CSS properties that require the use of the HTML5 doctype. Include it at the beginning of all your Wdesk projects.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
    ...
</html>

Mobile first

Web Skin is written to be mobile friendly from the start. Instead of adding on optional mobile styles, they’re baked right into the core. In fact, Web Skin is mobile first. Mobile first styles can be found throughout the entire library instead of in separate files.

To ensure proper rendering and touch zooming, add the viewport meta tag to your <head>.

<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">

Touch Friendly

Web Skin’s patterns have been designed and implemented to make the user experience just as enjoyable on a touch interface as it is on a traditional mouse/keyboard interface.

To ensure proper rendering of all interactions on a touch device, add the ontouchstart attribute to your <body>.

<body ontouchstart>
    ...
</body>

Responsive images

Images in your Wdesk app can be made responsive-friendly via the addition of Web Skin’s .img-responsive class. This applies max-width: 100%; and height: auto; to the image so that it scales nicely to the parent element.

<img src="..." class="img-responsive" alt="Reponsive image">

Typography and links

Web Skin sets basic global display, typography, and link styles. Specifically, we:

  • Remove margin on the body
  • Set background-color: $bodyBg; on the body
  • Use the $fontFamilyBase, $fontSizeBase, and $lineHeightBase Sass variables as our typographic base
  • Set the global link color via $linkColor and apply link underlines and $linkColorHover only on :hover

These styles can be found within _scaffolding.scss.

Normalize reset

For improved cross-browser rendering, we use Normalize, a project by Nicolas Gallagher and Jonathan Neal.

Centering with container

Easily center a page’s contents by wrapping its contents in a .container. Containers set max-width at various media query breakpoints to match our grid system.

<div class="container">
  ...
</div>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-grid:container  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Wide container

If your app needs to provide a more "full screen" experience for users, you can still center and baseline your grid columns by using the "wide" variant of the container.

<div class="container-wide">
  ...
</div>

Try on both containers for size!

If you’re looking to get a better feel for the differences between layout size/spacing inside of <div class="container"> and <div class="container-wide"> wrappers, Use the toggle button below to see the Web Skin documentation change it’s container as an example.

Grid system

Web Skin includes a responsive, mobile-first fluid grid system that appropriately scales up to columns as the device or viewport size increases. It includes predefined classes for easy layout options, as well as powerful mixins for generating more semantic layouts.

Introduction

Grid systems are used for creating page layouts through a series of rows and columns that house your content. Here’s how the Web Skin grid system works:

  • Rows must be placed within a .container (fixed-width) or .container-wide (full-width) for proper alignment and padding.
  • Use .rows to create horizontal groups of columns.
  • Content should be placed within columns, and only columns may be immediate children of rows.
  • Predefined grid classes like .row and .col-xs-4 are available for quickly making grid layouts. Sass mixins can also be used for more semantic layouts.
  • Columns create gutters (gaps between column content) via padding. That padding is offset in rows for the first and last column via negative margin on .rows.
  • Grid columns are created by specifying the number of available columns you wish to span. For example, three equal columns would use three .col-xs-4 elements.

Look to the grid examples for applying these principles to your code.

Media queries

We use the following media queries to create the key breakpoints in our grid system.

// Extra small devices (phones, up to 480px)
// No media query since this is the default in Web Skin (mobile first)

// Small devices (tablets, 768px and up)
@media (min-width: $screenTablet) { ... }

// Medium devices (tablets, 992px and up)
@media (min-width: $screenDesktop) { ... }

// Large devices (large desktops, 1200px and up)
@media (min-width: $screenDesktopLarge) { ... }

// Huge devices (huge desktops, 1600px and up)
@media (min-width: $screenDesktopHuge) { ... }

We occasionally expand on these media queries to include a max-width to limit CSS to a narrower set of devices.

@media (max-width: $screenPhoneMax) { ... }
@media (min-width: $screenTablet) and (max-width: $screenTabletMax) { ... }
@media (min-width: $screenDesktop) and (max-width: $screenDesktopMax) { ... }
@media (min-width: $screenDesktopLarge) and (max-width: $screenDesktopLargeMax) { ... }
@media (min-width: $screenDesktopHuge) { ... }

Grid options

See how aspects of the Web Skin grid system work across multiple devices with a handy table.

Extra Small devices
Phones (<) 		Small devices
Tablets (≥) 		Medium devices
Desktops (≥) 		Large devices
Desktops (≥) 		Huge devices
Desktops (>)
Grid behavior Horizontal at all times Collapsed to start, horizontal above breakpoints
Max container width None (auto)
Class prefix .col-xs- .col-sm- .col-md- .col-lg-
# of columns
Max column width Auto ~ ~ ~ ~
Gutter width ( on each side of a column)
Nestable Yes
Offsets Yes
Column ordering Yes

Grid classes apply to devices with screen widths greater than or equal to the breakpoint sizes, and override grid classes targeted at smaller devices. Therefore, applying any .col-md- class to an element will not only affect its styling on medium devices but also on large devices if a .col-lg- class is not present.

Example: Full-width container

Turn any fixed-width grid layout into a full-width layout by changing your outermost .container to .container-wide.

<div class="container-wide">
    <div class="row">
        ...
    </div>
</div>

Example: Mobile and desktop

Don’t want your columns to simply stack in smaller devices? Use the extra small and medium device grid classes by adding .col-xs-* .col-md-* to your columns. See the example below for a better idea of how it all works.

.col-xs-12 .col-md-8
.col-xs-6 .col-md-4
.col-xs-6 .col-md-4
.col-xs-6 .col-md-4
.col-xs-6 .col-md-4
.col-xs-6
.col-xs-6
<!-- Stack the columns on mobile by making one full-width and the other half-width -->
<div class="row">
    <div class="col-xs-12 col-md-8">.col-xs-12 .col-md-8</div>
    <div class="col-xs-6 col-md-4">.col-xs-6 .col-md-4</div>
</div>

<!-- Columns start at 50% wide on mobile and bump up to 33.3% wide on desktop -->
<div class="row">
    <div class="col-xs-6 col-md-4">.col-xs-6 .col-md-4</div>
    <div class="col-xs-6 col-md-4">.col-xs-6 .col-md-4</div>
    <div class="col-xs-6 col-md-4">.col-xs-6 .col-md-4</div>
</div>

<!-- Columns are always 50% wide, on mobile and desktop -->
<div class="row">
    <div class="col-xs-6">.col-xs-6</div>
    <div class="col-xs-6">.col-xs-6</div>
</div>

Example: Mobile, tablet, desktops

Build on the previous example by creating even more dynamic and powerful layouts with tablet .col-sm-* classes.

.col-xs-12 .col-sm-6 .col-md-8
.col-xs-6 .col-sm-6 .col-md-4
.col-xs-6 .col-sm-4 .col-md-4
.col-xs-6 .col-sm-4 .col-md-4
.col-xs-6 .col-sm-4 .col-md-4
<div class="row">
    <div class="col-xs-12 col-sm-6 col-md-8">.col-xs-12 .col-sm-6 .col-md-8</div>
    <div class="col-xs-6 col-sm-6 col-md-4">.col-xs-6 .col-sm-6 .col-md-4</div>
</div>
<div class="row">
    <div class="col-xs-6 col-sm-4 col-md-4">.col-xs-6 .col-sm-4 .col-md-4</div>
    <div class="col-xs-6 col-sm-4 col-md-4">.col-xs-6 .col-sm-4 .col-md-4</div>
    <!-- Optional: clear the XS cols if their content doesn't match in height -->
    <div class="clearfix visible-xs"></div>
    <div class="col-xs-6 col-sm-4 col-md-4">.col-xs-6 .col-sm-4 .col-md-4</div>
</div>

Responsive column resets

With the four tiers of grids available you’re bound to run into issues where, at certain breakpoints, your columns don’t clear quite right as one is taller than the other. To fix that, use a combination of a .clearfix and our responsive utility classes.

<div class="row">
    <div class="col-xs-6 col-sm-3">.col-xs-6 .col-sm-3</div>
    <div class="col-xs-6 col-sm-3">.col-xs-6 .col-sm-3</div>

    <!-- Add the extra clearfix for only the required viewport -->
    <div class="clearfix visible-xs"></div>

    <div class="col-xs-6 col-sm-3">.col-xs-6 .col-sm-3</div>
    <div class="col-xs-6 col-sm-3">.col-xs-6 .col-sm-3</div>
</div>

In addition to column clearing at responsive breakpoints, you may need to reset offsets, pushes, or pulls.

<div class="row">
    <div class="col-sm-5 col-md-6">.col-sm-5 .col-md-6</div>
    <div class="col-sm-5 col-sm-offset-2 col-md-6 col-md-offset-0">.col-sm-5 .col-sm-offset-2 .col-md-6 .col-md-offset-0</div>
</div>

<div class="row">
    <div class="col-sm-6 col-md-5 col-lg-6">.col-sm-6 .col-md-5 .col-lg-6</div>
    <div class="col-sm-6 col-md-5 col-md-offset-2 col-lg-6 col-lg-offset-0">.col-sm-6 .col-md-5 .col-md-offset-2 .col-lg-6 .col-lg-offset-0</div>
</div>

Offsetting columns

Move columns to the right using .col-md-offset-* classes. These classes increase the left margin of a column by * columns. For example, .col-md-offset-4 moves .col-md-4 over four columns.

.col-md-4
.col-md-4 .col-md-offset-4
.col-md-3 .col-md-offset-3
.col-md-3 .col-md-offset-3
.col-md-6 .col-md-offset-3
<div class="row">
    <div class="col-md-4">.col-md-4</div>
    <div class="col-md-4 col-md-offset-4">.col-md-4 .col-md-offset-4</div>
</div>
<div class="row">
    <div class="col-md-3 col-md-offset-3">.col-md-3 .col-md-offset-3</div>
    <div class="col-md-3 col-md-offset-3">.col-md-3 .col-md-offset-3</div>
</div>
<div class="row">
    <div class="col-md-6 col-md-offset-3">.col-md-6 .col-md-offset-3</div>
</div>

Nesting columns

To nest your content with the default grid, add a new .row and set of .col-md-* columns within an existing .col-md-* column. Nested rows should include a set of columns that add up to 12.

Level 1: .col-md-9
Level 2: .col-md-6
Level 2: .col-md-6 
<div class="row">
    <div class="col-md-9">
        Level 1: .col-md-9
        <div class="row">
            <div class="col-md-6">
                Level 2: .col-md-6
            </div>
            <div class="col-md-6">
                Level 2: .col-md-6
            </div>
        </div>
    </div>
</div>

Column ordering

Easily change the order of our built-in grid columns with .col-md-push-* and .col-md-pull-* modifier classes.

.col-md-9 .col-md-push-3
.col-md-3 .col-md-pull-9
<div class="row">
    <div class="col-md-9 col-md-push-3">.col-md-9 .col-md-push-3</div>
    <div class="col-md-3 col-md-pull-9">.col-md-3 .col-md-pull-9</div>
</div>

Sass mixins and variables

In addition to prebuilt grid classes for fast layouts, Web Skin includes Sass variables and mixins for quickly generating your own simple, semantic layouts.

Variables

Variables determine the number of columns, the gutter width, and the media query point at which to begin floating columns. We use these to generate the predefined grid classes documented above, as well as for the custom mixins listed below.

$gridColumns:             12;
$gridGutterWidth:         30px;
$gridFloatBreakpoint:     768px;

Mixins

Mixins are used in conjunction with the grid variables to generate semantic CSS for individual grid columns.

// Creates a wrapper for a series of columns
@mixin makeRow($gutter: $gridGutterWidth) {
    // Then clear the floated columns
    @include clearfix();

    @media (min-width: $screenTablet) {
        margin-left:  ($gutter / -2);
        margin-right: ($gutter / -2);
    }

    // Negative margin nested rows out to align the content of columns
    .row {
        margin-left:  ($gutter / -2);
        margin-right: ($gutter / -2);
    }
}

// Generate the extra small columns
@mixin makeXsColumn($columns, $gutter: $gridGutterWidth) {
    position: relative;
    // Prevent columns from collapsing when empty
    min-height: 1px;
    // Inner gutter via padding
    padding-left:  ($gutter / 2);
    padding-right: ($gutter / 2);

    // Calculate width based on number of columns available
    @media (min-width: $gridFloatBreakpoint) {
        float: left;
        width: percentage(($columns / $gridColumns));
    }
}

// Generate the small columns
@mixin makeSmColumn($columns, $gutter: $gridGutterWidth) {
    position: relative;
    // Prevent columns from collapsing when empty
    min-height: 1px;
    // Inner gutter via padding
    padding-left:  ($gutter / 2);
    padding-right: ($gutter / 2);

    // Calculate width based on number of columns available
    @media (min-width: $screenTablet) {
        float: left;
        width: percentage(($columns / $gridColumns));
    }
}

// Generate the small column offsets
@mixin makeSmColumnOffset($columns) {
    @media (min-width: $screenTablet) {
        margin-left: percentage(($columns / $gridColumns));
    }
}
@mixin makeSmColumnPush($columns) {
    @media (min-width: $screenTablet) {
        left: percentage(($columns / $gridColumns));
    }
}
@mixin makeSmColumnPull($columns) {
    @media (min-width: $screenTablet) {
        right: percentage(($columns / $gridColumns));
    }
}

// Generate the medium columns
@mixin makeMdColumn($columns, $gutter: $gridGutterWidth) {
    position: relative;
    // Prevent columns from collapsing when empty
    min-height: 1px;
    // Inner gutter via padding
    padding-left:  ($gutter / 2);
    padding-right: ($gutter / 2);

    // Calculate width based on number of columns available
    @media (min-width: $screenDesktop) {
        float: left;
        width: percentage(($columns / $gridColumns));
    }
}

// Generate the medium column offsets
@mixin makeMdColumnOffset($columns) {
    @media (min-width: $screenDesktop) {
        margin-left: percentage(($columns / $gridColumns));
    }
}
@mixin makeMdColumnPush($columns) {
    @media (min-width: $screenDesktop) {
        left: percentage(($columns / $gridColumns));
    }
}
@mixin makeMdColumnPull($columns) {
    @media (min-width: $screenDesktop) {
        right: percentage(($columns / $gridColumns));
    }
}

// Generate the large columns
@mixin makeLgColumn($columns, $gutter: $gridGutterWidth) {
    position: relative;
    // Prevent columns from collapsing when empty
    min-height: 1px;
    // Inner gutter via padding
    padding-left:  ($gutter / 2);
    padding-right: ($gutter / 2);

    // Calculate width based on number of columns available
    @media (min-width: $screenDesktopLarge) {
        float: left;
        width: percentage(($columns / $gridColumns));
    }
}

// Generate the large column offsets
@mixin makeLgColumnOffset($columns) {
    @media (min-width: $screenDesktopLarge) {
        margin-left: percentage(($columns / $gridColumns));
    }
}
@mixin makeLgColumnPush($columns) {
    @media (min-width: $screenDesktopLarge) {
        left: percentage(($columns / $gridColumns));
    }
}
@mixin makeLgColumnPull($columns) {
    @media (min-width: $screenDesktopLarge) {
        right: percentage(($columns / $gridColumns));
    }
}

Example usage

You can modify the variables to your own custom values, or just use the mixins with their default values. Here’s an example of using the default settings to create a two-column layout with a gap between.

.wrapper {
    @include makeRow();
}
.content-main {
    @include makeLgColumn(8);
}
.content-secondary {
    @include makeLgColumn(3);
    @include makeLgColumnOffset(1);
}
<div class="wrapper">
    <div class="content-main">...</div>
    <div class="content-secondary">...</div>
</div>

Typography

Everything from our standard headings to body copy, blockquotes, lists and more!

Typographic scale

Powered by Sass: The typographic scale is based on two Sass variables in _variables.scss: $fontSizeBase and $lineHeightBase. The first is the base font-size used throughout and the second is the base line-height.

We use those variables and some simple math to create the margins, paddings, and line-heights of all our typography, components and more. Customize them and Web Skin adapts.

Headings

All HTML headings, <h1> through <h6> are available.

Wdesk Main Title <h1> Gibson Regular 36px
Wdesk Super Header <h2> Gibson Regular 24px
Wdesk heading <h3> Gibson Semibold 18px
Wdesk heading <h4> Gibson Semibold 16px
Wdesk heading <h5> Gibson Semibold 14px
Wdesk heading <h6> Gibson Regular 14px

Gibson Webfont not available in MSIE 8 or below

Because Gibson cannot be properly aliased by Internet Explorer 8 or below, all headings will use the native Arial/Helvetica sans-serif font.

See Issue #607 for more information.

Jumbotron Header

A lightweight, flexible component to showcase key content on your site. It works well on marketing and content-heavy areas.

Hello, world!

This is a simple hero unit, a simple jumbotron-style component for calling extra attention to featured content or information.

Learn more

<div class="jumbotron">
    <h1>Hello, world!</h1>
    <p>...</p>
    <p><a class="btn btn-alt btn-lg btn-callout">Learn more</a></p>
</div>

Page header

A simple shell for an h1 to appropriately space out and segment sections of content on a page. It can utilize the h1's default small, element as well most other components (with additional styles).

Example page header Subtext for header

<div class="page-header">
    <h1>Example page header <small>Subtext for header</small></h1>
</div>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-page-header  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Body copy

Web Skin’s global default font-size is , with a line-height of . This is applied to the <body> and all paragraphs. In addition, <p> (paragraphs) receive a bottom margin of half their line-height ( by default).

Nullam quis risus eget urna mollis ornare vel eu leo. Cum sociis natoque penatibus et magnis dis parturient montes, nascetur ridiculus mus. Nullam id dolor id nibh ultricies vehicula.

Cum sociis natoque penatibus et magnis dis parturient montes, nascetur ridiculus mus. Donec ullamcorper nulla non metus auctor fringilla. Duis mollis, est non commodo luctus, nisi erat porttitor ligula, eget lacinia odio sem nec elit. Donec ullamcorper nulla non metus auctor fringilla.

Maecenas sed diam eget risus varius blandit sit amet non magna. Donec id elit non mi porta gravida at eget metus. Duis mollis, est non commodo luctus, nisi erat porttitor ligula, eget lacinia odio sem nec elit.

<p>...</p>

Lead body copy

Make a paragraph stand out by adding .lead.

Vivamus sagittis lacus vel augue laoreet rutrum faucibus dolor auctor. Duis mollis, est non commodo luctus.

<p class="lead">...</p>

Hyperlinks

Bring attention to links that help your users navigate through your site or application.

Standard hyperlink

This is the main paragraph text which contains a hyperlink to give the user a cue that something will happen if they click it.

<p>... <a href="#">hyperlink</a> ...</p>

Header hyperlink

When a heading on a page must be used as a hyperlink, use the .header-link utility class to make the hyperlink inherit the heading’s color, while still providing a cue for the user on hover.

Header link (hover me)

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat. Duis aute irure dolor in reprehenderit in voluptate velit esse cillum dolore eu fugiat nulla pariatur. Excepteur sint occaecat cupidatat non proident, sunt in culpa qui officia deserunt mollit anim id est laborum.

Typographic Variations

Make use of HTML’s default emphasis tags, and some custom CSS classes of our own to get your type just right.

Size

Small text

For de-emphasizing inline or blocks of text, use the <small> tag to set text to (roughly the size of the parent).

This is the main paragraph text.
This line of text is meant to be treated as fine print.

<p>...<small>This line of text is meant to be treated as fine print.</small></p>

Medium text

Easily keep components looking how-they-did before Web Skin came along for Wdesk apps by adding the .text-md CSS class. This makes all non-heading text .

Default

Nullam quis risus eget urna mollis ornare vel eu leo. Cum sociis natoque penatibus et magnis dis parturient montes, nascetur ridiculus mus. Nullam id dolor id nibh ultricies vehicula.

Cum sociis natoque penatibus et magnis dis parturient montes, nascetur ridiculus mus. Donec ullamcorper nulla non metus auctor fringilla. Duis mollis, est non commodo luctus, nisi erat porttitor ligula, eget lacinia odio sem nec elit. Donec ullamcorper nulla non metus auctor fringilla.

header header header
data data data
data data data
data data data

Text ("legacy")

Nullam quis risus eget urna mollis ornare vel eu leo. Cum sociis natoque penatibus et magnis dis parturient montes, nascetur ridiculus mus. Nullam id dolor id nibh ultricies vehicula.

Cum sociis natoque penatibus et magnis dis parturient montes, nascetur ridiculus mus. Donec ullamcorper nulla non metus auctor fringilla. Duis mollis, est non commodo luctus, nisi erat porttitor ligula, eget lacinia odio sem nec elit. Donec ullamcorper nulla non metus auctor fringilla.

header header header
data data data
data data data
data data data 
<!-- Default -->
<p>...</p>
<table class="table">
    ...
</table>

<!-- Medium ("legacy") -->
<p class="text-md">...</p>
<table class="table text-md">
    ...
</table>

Large text

To increase the font-size of a piece of text, use the .text-lg utility class to set text to .

This is the text that should be larger.
This line of text is the default font-size.

<p><span class="text-lg">This is the text that should be larger.</span> ...</p>

Weight

Wrap text in a <strong> tag, or add the text-bold CSS class to any inline-element to emphasize it with a heavier font-weight.

The following snippet of text is rendered as bold text.

This snippet of text uses a CSS class instead of STRONG to produce bold text.

<p>The following snippet of text is <strong>rendered as bold text</strong>.</p>
<p>... <span class="text-bold">bold text</span>.</p>

Style

Wrap text in a <em> tag, or add the text-italic CSS class to any inline-element to emphasize it with an italicized font-face.

The following snippet of text is rendered as italicized text.

This snippet of text uses a CSS class instead of EM to produce italicized text.

<p>The following snippet of text is <em>rendered as italicized text</em>.</p>
<p>... <span class="text-italic">italicized text</span>.</p>

Old HTML 4 elements

Feel free to use the old <b> and <i> in HTML5. <b> is meant to highlight words or phrases without conveying additional importance while <i> is mostly for voice, technical terms, etc.

Color

Convey meaning through color with a handful of utility classes.

Muting

Tone down the saturation of a given piece of text using the text-muted CSS class.

Part of this paragraph is muted

Part of this hyperlink is muted

This entire hyperlink is muted

This paragraph has a portion of it muted, with a hyperlink inside the muted element

<p>Part of this paragraph <span class="text-muted">is muted</span></p>
<p><a href="#">Part of this hyperlink <span class="text-muted">is muted</span></a></p>
<p><a class="text-muted" href="#">This entire hyperlink is muted</a></p>
<p>This paragraph has a <span class="text-muted">portion of it muted, with <a href="#">a hyperlink inside</a> the muted element</span></p>

State

Demonstrate the current state of an application or process by using the text-{state} CSS classes.

Confirmation: Something happened, I swear.

Well done! You successfully read this important alert message.

Heads up! If you proceed with this action, there could be consequences.

Oh snap! Change a few things up and try submitting again.

<p class="text-alt"><strong>Confirmation:</strong> ...</p>
<p class="text-success"><strong>Well done!</strong> ...</p>
<p class="text-warning"><strong>Heads up!</strong> ...</p>
<p class="text-error"><strong>Oh snap!</strong> ...</p>

Zesty Crayon

The row labeled “main” in the Zesty Crayon Color Palette is available via CSS classes to make your text as Zesty as anyone could ever imagine.

greenAlt2 - which can also be muted

greenAlt1 - which can also be muted

Alignment options

Easily realign text to components with text alignment classes.

Left aligned text.

Center aligned text.

Right aligned text.

<p class="text-left">Left aligned text.</p>
<p class="text-center">Center aligned text.</p>
<p class="text-right">Right aligned text.</p>

Abbreviations

Stylized implementation of HTML’s <abbr> element for abbreviations and acronyms to show the expanded version on hover. Abbreviations with a title attribute have a light dotted bottom border and a help cursor on hover, providing additional context on hover.

Basic abbreviation

For expanded text on long hover of an abbreviation, include the title attribute with the <abbr> element.

An abbreviation of the word attribute is attr.

<abbr title="attribute">attr</abbr>

Initialism

Add .initialism to an abbreviation for a slightly smaller font-size.

HTML is the best thing since sliced bread.

<abbr title="HyperText Markup Language" class="initialism">HTML</abbr>

Addresses

Present contact information for the nearest ancestor or the entire body of work. Preserve formatting by ending all lines with <br>.

Workiva
2900 University Blvd.
Ames, IA 50010
P: (888) 275-3125
Full Name
first.last@workiva.com 
<address>
    <strong>Workiva</strong><br>
    2900 University Blvd.<br>
    Ames, IA 50010<br>
    <abbr title="Phone">P:</abbr> (888) 275-3125
</address>

<address>
    <strong>Full Name</strong><br>
    <a href="mailto:#">first.last@workiva.com</a>
</address>

Blockquotes

For quoting blocks of content from another source within your document.

Default blockquote

Wrap <blockquote> around any HTML as the quote. For straight quotes we recommend a <p>.

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Integer posuere erat a ante.

<blockquote>
    <p>Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Integer posuere erat a ante.</p>
</blockquote>

Blockquote options

Style and content changes for simple variations on a standard blockquote.

Naming a source

Add <small> tag for identifying the source. Wrap the name of the source work in <cite>.

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Integer posuere erat a ante.

Someone famous in Source Title 
<blockquote>
    <p>Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Integer posuere erat a ante.</p>
    <small>Someone famous <cite title="Source Title">Source Title</cite></small>
</blockquote>

Alternate displays

Use .pull-right for a floated, right-aligned blockquote.

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Integer posuere erat a ante.

Someone famous in Source Title 
<blockquote class="pull-right">
    ...
</blockquote>

Wordy

Sometimes bullet-points can be a tad lengthy - making them difficult to read on multiple lines. Add the .list-wordy class to any list to bump up the spacing between list items.

  • Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.

    <li>...</li>
</ul>

Remove the default list-style and left padding on list items (immediate children only).

Horizontal description

Make terms and descriptions in <dl> line up side-by-side. Starts off stacked like default <dl>s, but when the grid columns expand, so do these.

Description lists
A description list is perfect for defining terms.
Euismod
Vestibulum id ligula porta felis euismod semper eget lacinia odio sem nec elit.
Donec id elit non mi porta gravida at eget metus.
Malesuada porta
Etiam porta sem malesuada magna mollis euismod.
Felis euismod semper eget lacinia
Fusce dapibus, tellus ac cursus commodo, tortor mauris condimentum nibh, ut fermentum massa justo sit amet risus.
<dl class="dl-horizontal">
    <dt>...</dt>
    <dd>...</dd>
</dl>

Auto-truncating

Horizontal description lists will truncate terms that are too long to fit in the left column with text-overflow. In narrower viewports, they will change to the default stacked layout.

Code

Inline

Wrap inline snippets of code with <code>.

For example, <section> should be wrapped as inline. 
For example, <code>&lt;section&gt;</code> should be wrapped as inline.

User input

Use the <kbd> to indicate input that is typically entered via keyboard.

To switch directories, type cd followed by the name of the directory. 
To switch directories, type <kbd>cd</kbd> followed by the name of the directory.

Basic block

Use <pre> for multiple lines of code. Be sure to escape any angle brackets in the code for proper rendering.

<p>Sample text here...</p>
<pre>&lt;p&gt;Sample text here...&lt;/p&gt;</pre>

Scrollable code blocks

You may optionally add the .pre-scrollable class which will set a max-height of and provide a y-axis scrollbar.

Color palette

These are the “Zesty Crayon” colors made available by Web Skin. Use this for visual reference, or reference them in your project by extending Web Skin with Sass.

Color Meanings

Color Meaning
Primary / Success
Green is the Wdesk brand color. Shows creation and actions initiated by the user. Communicates success in messaging.
Alternate / Transition
Demonstrates secondary emphasis within layout. Also used to illustrate transitions. In messaging, communicates information.
Warning
Shows points of caution and highlights destructive actions. Used in messaging to warn users about potentially harmful actions.
Help
To communicate a helpful action / messaging
Error / Danger
Communicates irreversible actions and severe errors. Should be used sparingly in messaging. For cautions and recoverable problems, consider Orange instead.
Default
Color used for all non-emphasized actions and messaging. Also employed for main body copy.

Tables

Used for… you guessed it… displaying tabular-data to Wdesk users.

Basic example

For basic styling, cell padding and only horizontal dividers — add the base .table CSS class to any <table>.

It may seem super redundant to add a CSS class named “table” to a <table> element, but given the widespread use of tables for third-party platforms/plugins, we’ve opted to isolate our custom table styles to a CSS class rather than defaulting them on the base element.

List of people’s names and their Twitter handles
# First Name Last Name Twitter Handle
1 Aaron Lademann @alademann
2 Jason Moore @mooreplusone
3 John Bland @johncblandii 
<table class="table">
    ...
</table>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-table  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Supported table markup

Below is a list of supported table HTML elements and how they should be used.

This table lists the HTML tags that are supported within table elements when using the Web Skin platform.
Tag Description
<table> Wrapping element for displaying data in a tabular format
<thead> Container element for table header rows
<tbody> Container element for table body rows
<tr> Container element for a row of one or more table cells
<td> Default table cell (nested within <tbody> elem only)
<th>

Heading table cell used to label columns or rows, depending on scope and placement. Use of the scope attribute is especially important for accessibility.

<table class="table">
    <!-- th cells in thead rows should be scoped for columns -->
    <thead>
        <tr>
            <th scope="col">Name</th>
            <th scope="col">Location</th>
            <th scope="col">Job Title</th>
        </tr>
    </thead>
    <!-- th cells in tbody rows should be scoped for rows -->
    <tbody>
        <tr>
            <th scope="row">Jason Moore</th>
            <td>Scottsdale, Arizona</td>
            <td>UX Lead</td>
        </tr>
    </tbody>
</table>
<caption> Recommended Description or summary of what the table holds, especially useful for screen reader accessibility when combined with our .sr-only CSS helper class
<colgroup> Optional Specifies a group of one or more columns in a table for formatting
<col> Optional Specifies column properties for each column within a <colgroup> element

Accessible markup

Putting it all together, a well-formed and accessible table that is WCAG 2.0 compliant will look something like this:

<table class="table">
        <caption class="sr-only">Describe the contents of the table</caption>
        <!-- OPTIONAL COLGROUP -->
        <colgroup>
            <col>
            <col>
            <col>
        </colgroup>
        <thead>
            <tr>
                <th scope="col">Describe the contents of the first column</th>
                <th scope="col">Describe the contents of the second column</th>
                <th scope="col">Describe the contents of the third column</th>
            </tr>
        </thead>
        <tbody>
            <tr>
                <th scope="row">Describe the contents of the row</th>
                <td>...</td>
                <td>...</td>
            </tr>
        </tbody>
    </table>

Table variations

Add any of the following classes to the base .table CSS class to control the appearance / behavior of an entire table.

Condensed tables

Add .table-condensed to make tables more compact by cutting cell padding in half.

List of people’s names and their Twitter handles
# First Name Last Name Twitter Handle
1 Aaron Lademann @alademann
2 Jason Moore @mooreplusone
3 John Bland @johncblandii 
<table class="table table-condensed">
    ...
</table>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-table:condensed  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Striped tables

Use .table-striped to add zebra-striping to any table row within the <tbody>.

Cross-browser compatibility

Striped tables are styled via the :nth-child CSS selector, which is not available in Internet Explorer 8 or below.

List of people’s names and their Twitter handles
# First Name Last Name Twitter Handle
1 Aaron Lademann @alademann
2 Jason Moore @mooreplusone
3 John Bland @johncblandii 
<table class="table table-striped">
    ...
</table>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-table:striped  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Bordered tables

Add .table-bordered for borders on all sides of the table and cells, and a more “contained” look for the table header.

List of people’s names and their Twitter handles
# First Name Last Name Twitter Handle
1 Aaron Lademann @alademann
2 Jason Moore @mooreplusone
3 John Bland @johncblandii

    ...

SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-table:bordered  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Vertically bordered tables

Add .table-bordered-vertical in addition to .table-bordered for a table with no horizontal borders on it’s rows within the <tbody> element in a table.

Always Stripe Vertically Bordered Tables

Since tables with only vertical borders will inherently lack a divider between rows, it is recommended that you only use this pattern in combination with the striped table variation as shown in our example.

List of people’s names and their Twitter handles
# First Name Last Name Twitter Handle
1 Aaron Lademann @alademann
2 Jason Moore @mooreplusone
3 John Bland @johncblandii

</table>

Sortable tables

Add .table-sortable to any table and use a nested <i class="caret"> elem to indicate that a table is comprised of sortable rows.

Custom JS Required

The example below is to demonstrate visual pattern only. It does not actively sort this table, and when implementing in your app, you will have to wire up the sorting functionality via a click on the <thead> <th> elem.

# First Name Last Name Twitter Handle
1 Aaron Lademann @alademann
2 Jason Moore @mooreplusone
3 John Bland @johncblandii 
<table class="table table-sortable">
    <colgroup>
        <col class="col-xs-1">
        <col class="col-xs-3">
        <col class="col-xs-5">
        <col class="col-xs-3">
    </colgroup>
    <thead>
        <tr>
            <th scope="col">#
                <i class="caret" aria-hidden="true"></i>
            </th>
            <th scope="col" class="sorted ascending">First Name
                <i class="caret" aria-hidden="true"></i>
            </th>
            <th scope="col">Last Name
                <i class="caret" aria-hidden="true"></i>
            </th>
            <th scope="col">Twitter Handle
                <i class="caret" aria-hidden="true"></i>
            </th>
        </tr>
    </thead>
    ...
</table>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-table:sortable  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Specifying unsortable columns

When implementing a Web Skin sortable table, you may have certain columns that are not sortable in certain view states / or not sortable at all. You can remove the hover visual treatment of a column header cell by applying the .unsortable CSS class as shown in the “Last Signed On” header below.

Click functionality of unsortable column header

The .unsortable class will only change the appearance of the <th> elements, not their functionality. You must tweak your app’s logic to respect the presence of this class so that clicking it doesn’t attempt to sort your table.

# First Name Last Name Last Signed On Twitter Handle
1 Aaron Lademann Yesterday 3:45pm @alademann
2 Jason Moore Three days ago @mooreplusone
3 John Bland Yesterday 1:25am @johncblandii 
<table class="table table-sortable">
    <thead>
        <tr>
            ...
            <th scope="col" class="unsortable">
                Last Signed On
                <!--
                    The .caret elem can be removed since it's unsortable,
                    but if your template logic doesn't remove it when a
                    column is unsortable - have no fear, it won't show up anyway.
                -->
                <i class="caret" aria-hidden="true"></i>
            </th>
            ...
        </tr>
    </thead>
    ...
</table>

Selectable table rows

Add .table-selectable to any table to indicate that a table is comprised of selectable rows.

Custom JS Required

Note that you would actually have to wire up the data-ng-click via AngularJS (or any other JS library you’re using) on each row for something to actually happen on click.

Indeterminate Checkbox State

In order to control the “indeterminate” state of the “parent” checkbox in the header, manipulate the native JS checkbox.intederminate property - or use jQuery’'s $(checkbox).prop('indeterminate', true). See this article for more information.

Responsive tables

Column sizing

Use Web Skin’s grid system and the table <col> / <colgroup> elements to make flexible column sizing a simple reality.

Col 1 Col 2 Col 3
.col-xs-2 .col-xs-3 .col-xs-7 
<table class="table table-bordered">
    <colgroup>
        <col class="col-xs-2">
        <col class="col-xs-3">
        <col class="col-xs-7">
    </colgroup>
    <!-- number of <td>/<th> elems in <thead> and/or <tbody> must match number of <col> elems in <colgroup> -->
    <tbody>
        <tr>
            <td>...</td>
            <td>...</td>
            <td>...</td>
        </tr>
    </tbody>
</table>

Fixed column width CSS recommendations

To make your tables with fixed-width columns appear like the sortable and selectable table examples in these docs, utilize the recommended styles described below.

  1. Because of the way table columns scale in size according to their contents by default, we recommend adding the following CSS rule for any table using fixed column widths: 
    .table-with-fixed-col-widths {
    table-layout: fixed;
}
  2. When using fixed widths on table columns, column headers are prone to breaking onto a second line of text, causing unexpected visual results. To prevent this, we recommend setting the following CSS rules for header columns: 
    .table-with-fixed-col-widths > thead > th {
    overflow: hidden;
    white-space: nowrap;
    text-overflow: ellipsis;
}

Empty search results panel

When using tables to display filtered data to a user, use the panel component to display an empty results message to the user when no rows are being displayed.

# First Name Last Name Twitter Handle

Import from your computer or create something new.

Horizontal form

Right align labels and float them to the left to make them appear on the same line as controls. Use Web Skin’s predefined grid classes to align labels and groups of form controls. Doing so changes .form-groups to behave as grid rows, so no need for .row.

Appending right-aligned form labels

With .form-horizontal forms, labels are right-aligned. Always append right-aligned labels with : as shown in the example below.

Contact information

            </label>

                       class="form-control"
                       placeholder="Email">
            </div>

                   class="col-sm-2 control-label">

            </label>
            <div class="col-sm-10">

Form Accessibility

Take note of the form control markup shown in this section as it is essential to ensure that your forms are compliant according to WCAG 2.0. Detailed requirements are listed below.

Every control requires a label

In an implementation like the one shown in our inline form example where the “label” text for an input is shown via the placeholder attribute value, Screen readers will have trouble if you don’t also include an actual <label> for every input. In these situations, you should hide the labels using the .sr-only CSS class.

<form class="form-inline">
    <div class="form-group">
        <label for="{{ control-id }}" class="sr-only">Email address</label>
        <input type="email" id="{{ control-id }}" class="form-control" placeholder="Email">
    </div>
</form>

Control grouping

  1. Use <fieldset> elements to group multiple form controls together that are all related to the context provided by the <legend>
  2. Label groups of form controls using a <legend> to provide a heading context within a <fieldset>
<form>
    <fieldset>
        <legend>Contact information</legend>

        <div class="form-group">
            <label for="{{ name-control-id }}">Name</label>
            <input type="text" id="{{ name-control-id }}" class="form-control">
        </div>
        <div class="form-group">
            <label for="{{ email-control-id }}">Email</label>
            <input type="email" id="{{ email-control-id }}" class="form-control">
        </div>
        <div class="form-group">
            <label for="{{ tel-control-id }}">Phone</label>
            <input type="tel" id="{{ tel-control-id }}" class="form-control">
        </div>
    </fieldset>
</form>

Input control types

Use appropriate type value for all <input> elements. Web Skin supports the following input types:

  1. text
  2. email
  3. tel
  4. number
  5. password
  6. url
  7. search
  8. color
  9. datetime
  10. datetime-local
  11. date
  12. month
  13. time
  14. week

Supported form controls

Examples of standard form controls supported in an example form layout.

Inputs

Most common form control, text-based input fields. Includes support for all HTML5 input types.

Type declaration required

Inputs will only be fully styled if their HTML5 input type is properly declared.

Input placeholder support

The placeholder attribute is not supported by MSIE 9 or below.

In order to make them work in crappy browsers, include Web Skin’s libs_ie.js file in your app, and run the following on page load:

$('input[placeholder], textarea[placeholder]').placeholder();
<label for="{{ input-id }}" class="sr-only">Text input name</label>
<input type="text" id="{{ input-id }}" class="form-control" placeholder="Text input">
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-input:{type}  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Number inputs

Number input type support

<input type="number"> is not natively supported by MSIE 9 or below.

In order to make them work in crappy browsers, include Web Skin’s libs_ie.js file in your app so we can provide a polyfill for it.

<label for="{{ number-input-id }}" class="sr-only">Number input name</label>
<input type="number" id="{{ number-input-id }}" class="form-control" placeholder="Number input">

Search inputs

Wrap your search input in a .search-box to give the user an easy way to clear their search query that looks the same in all browsers! Check out the icon glyph search system to see it action.

<div role="search" class="search-box">
    <label for="{{ search-id }}" class="sr-only">Search</label>
    <input type="search" id="{{ search-id }}" class="form-control search-text" placeholder="Search">
    <i class="icon icon-search" aria-hidden="true"></i>
    <button type="button" aria-hidden="true" class="btn clear-search" title="Clear Search">
        <i class="sr-only">Clear Search</i>
        <i aria-hidden="true">&times;</i>
    </button>
</div>

Plugin dependency

The search field example above utilizes our buttons plugin to easily bind the clear button to the search input.

$('.clear-search').button('clearSearch');

Textarea

Form control which supports multiple lines of text. Change rows attribute as necessary.

<label for="{{ textarea-id }}">Textarea name</label>
<textarea id="{{ textarea-id }}" class="form-control" rows="3" placeholder="Start typing..."></textarea>

“Pretty” Checkboxes & Radio Buttons

Leading up to the 0.5.0 release, you must add the .checkbox-pretty or .radio-pretty CSS class in order to get the custom visual treatment on those buttons. Once 0.5.0 is released, this class will no longer be necessary, and the markup which wraps the <label> elem around the <input> will be deprecated.

Need assistance migrating to the new “pretty” checkboxes?
Give us a shout or open an issue.

Browser / Device Support

If your product needs to support Touch Devices, or MSIE 8 or below, you must include the buttons plugin in your app.

Scales with font size

Checkboxes and Radio buttons will change their size based on the font-size of their parent element. Apply a font-size to the individual .checkbox or .radio elems, or change the font-size of an entire form or fieldset - the controls will adapt!

Checkbox default font size demo
Checkbox large font size demo
Checkbox large font size demo 2

        <legend class="sr-only">Inherits font-size from fieldset</legend>

        <div class="checkbox checkbox-pretty">
            <input type="checkbox" id="{{ checkbox-id }}">
            <label for="{{ checkbox-id }}">Larger Font Size</label>
        </div>
        <div class="radio radio-pretty">
            <input type="radio" name="{{ options-name }}" id="{{ radio-id }}" value="option1" checked>
            <label for="{{ radio-id }}">Larger Font Size</label>
        </div>
    </fieldset>
    <fieldset>
        <legend class="sr-only">font-size applied directly to checkbox/radio</legend>

        <div class="checkbox checkbox-pretty text-lg">
            <input type="checkbox" id="{{ checkbox-id }}" value="">
            <label for="{{ checkbox-id }}">Larger Font Size</label>
        </div>
        <div class="radio radio-pretty text-lg">
            <input type="radio" name="{{ options-name }}" id="{{ radio-id }}" value="option1" checked>
            <label for="{{ radio-id }}">Larger Font Size</label>
        </div>
    </fieldset>
</form>

Customizing Toggle Labels

By default, toggle switches use labels "on" and "off". In order to customize this, give your toggle a custom class, and add the following to your project’s Sass.

The mixin shown being used below will set up the labels, and will also make sure the toggle is the correct width to accomodate the length of your labels.

Toggle switch label customization demo 
<div class="checkbox-switch my-custom-switch">
    <input type="checkbox" id="{{ switch-id-one }}">
    <label for="{{ switch-id-one }}"></label>
</div>
<div class="checkbox-switch checkbox-switch-xs my-custom-switch">
    <input type="checkbox" id="{{ switch-id-two }}">
    <label for="{{ switch-id-two }}"></label>
</div>
// example of a switch for toggling a comment type
.my-custom-switch {
    @include checkboxSwitchText(
        $defaultText: "private",
        $checkedText: "shared"
    );
    // if its a certain size variation, be sure to include that parameter
    &.checkbox-switch-xs {
        @include checkboxSwitchText(
            $defaultText: "private",
            $checkedText: "shared",
            $sizeVariation: "xs"
        );
    }
}

Extending Web Skin Sass Required

The above toggle label customization example assumes your project’s Sass is set up to extend Web Skin’s Sass.

Placeholders for non-multiple selects

For <select multiple> elements, the data-placeholder attribute is all you’ll need to display a placeholder value when no selection has been made. However, for non-multiple select elements - you must add a selected option in order to display the placeholder. We suggest disabling it for accessibility purposes.

<select class="chosen form-control">
    <option disabled selected>Choose a Doctype</option>
    <option>10-K</option>
    <option>10-Q</option>
    ...
</select>

Form control states

Provide feedback to users with basic feedback states on form controls and labels.

Input focus

The input below is simulating what a focused input looks like.

<label for="{{ input-id }}" class="sr-only">Input name</label>
<input type="{{ input-type }}" id="{{ input-id }}" class="form-control" value="This is focused...">

Invalid inputs

Style inputs via default browser functionality with :invalid. Specify a type, add the required and aria-required="true" attributes if the field is not optional, and (if applicable) specify a pattern.

<label for="{{ input-id }}">Input name</label>
<input type="{{ input-type }}" id="{{ input-id }}" class="form-control"
       required
       aria-required="true">

Not supported in MSIE 9 or lower

This is not available in versions of Internet Explorer 9 or below due to lack of support for CSS pseudo selectors.

Required field label

The above example utilitzes the .required CSS class on it’s label to ensure users know which field is required.

<label for="{{ input-id }}" class="required">Email:</label>

Disabled checkboxes & radio buttons

In order to properly disable a checkbox or radio button, add the .disabled CSS class to the .radio, .radio-inline, .checkbox or .checkbox-inline element that is wrapped around the input itself.

<div class="checkbox checkbox-pretty disabled">
    <input type="checkbox" id="{{ checkbox-id }}"
           disabled>
    <label for="{{ checkbox-id }}">Checkbox name</label>
</div>
<div class="radio radio-pretty disabled">
    <input type="radio" name="{{ radio-group-name }}" id="{{ radio-id }}"
           disabled
           checked>
    <label for="{{ radio-id }}">Radio button name</label>
</div>

Functionality of <input> not impacted

The .disabled CSS class will only change the appearance of <input type="checkbox"> and <input type="radio"> elements, not their functionality. Use custom JS to disable the inputs contained within the wrapping element. We’ve provided a suggestion below.

var $disabledCboxes = $('.checkbox.disabled, .checkbox-inline.disabled,
                         .radio.disabled, .radio-inline.disabled', document.body);
$('> input', $disabledCboxes).prop('disabled', true);

Disabled inputs

Add the disabled attribute on an input to prevent user input and trigger a slightly different look.

<label for="{{ input-id }}">Disabled input name</label>
<input type="text" id="{{ input-id }}" class="form-control"
       placeholder="Disabled input here..."
       disabled>

Readonly inputs

Add the readonly attribute on an input to prevent user input and trigger a similar "disabled" look that still allows text selection.

<label for="{{ input-id }}">Readonly input name</label>
<input type="tel" id="{{ input-id }}" class="form-control"
       value="555-432-5665"
       readonly>

“Vanilla” inputs

Add the .input-vanilla class to any input to simply “print” the value of an input - without decorating it like an input field - while maintaining its alignment / spacing amongst other fields in the form.

<label for="{{ input-id }}">Vanilla input name</label>
<input type="text" id="{{ input-id }}" class="form-control input-vanilla"
       value="000123456"
       readonly>

Form validation

Web Skin includes validation styles for error, warning, and success states on form controls. To use, add .has-warning, .has-error, or .has-success to the parent element. Any .control-label, input, textarea, select, and .help-block within that element will receive the validation styles.

Validation tooltips

In the demo below, we’re also using our tooltip plugin in combination with tooltip color variations to provide the user with an extra level of feedback.

Remember to always keep your tooltip validation messages short ’n sweet, between 4 and 8 words.

Click on the “Validation JS” tab to the right of the markup to see an example of how this can be implemented.

Form validation tooltip demo
  • Validation HTML
  • Validation JS 
<form class="form-horizontal">
    <fieldset>
        <legend class="sr-only">Description of these inputs</legend>

        <div class="form-group has-warning">
            <label for="inputOne" class="col-md-3 control-label">...</label>
            <div class="col-md-9 controls">
                <input type="text" id="inputOne" class="form-control"
                       data-toggle="tooltip"
                       title="Important warning message!">
            </div>
        </div>
        <div class="form-group has-error">
            <label for="inputTwo" class="col-md-3 control-label">...</label>
            <div class="col-md-9 controls">
                <input type="text" id="inputTwo" class="form-control"
                       data-toggle="tooltip"
                       title="Critical error message!">
            </div>
        </div>
        <div class="form-group has-success">
            <label for="inputThree" class="col-md-3 control-label">...</label>
            <div class="col-md-9 controls">
                <input type="text" id="inputThree" class="form-control"
                       data-toggle="tooltip"
                       title="Uplifting success message!">
            </div>
        </div>
    </fieldset>
</form>
//
// This is only a suggestion about how you
// COULD implement form-validation tooltips.
// It is NOT the required method for doing so.
//
// For this demonstration, we&rsquo;re going to
// assume your JS implementation is providing
// you with the field that has a validation state
// that needs messaging as a jQuery object
//

var $validatedField = jQueryObjectYourAppWouldProvide();

$validatedField.tooltip({
    trigger:    'focus',
    placement:  'right auto',
    container:  'body',
    template:   getValidationTooltipTemplate($validatedField);
});

function getValidationTooltipTemplate ($input) {
    var $formGroup = $input.closest('.form-group');
    var templateConstant = '<div class="arrow" aria-hidden="true"></div><div class="inner"></div></div>';

    if ($formGroup.hasClass('has-warning')) {
        template = '<div class="tooltip tooltip-warning">' + templateConstant;
    } else if ($formGroup.hasClass('has-error')) {
        template = '<div class="tooltip tooltip-error">' + templateConstant;
    } else if ($formGroup.hasClass('has-success')) {
        template = '<div class="tooltip tooltip-success">' + templateConstant;
    } else {
        // something went wrong... don't know which type of validation tooltip you need
        // could either break out here, or throw an error.
    }

    return template;
}

Help text

Block level help text for form controls.

Within a vertical form
A longer block of help text that is within a .form-group element, and may extend beyond one line.
A longer block of help text that is not within a .form-group element, and may extend beyond one line. 
<form class="form-vertical">
    <fieldset>
        <legend>...</legend>

        <div class="col-md-8 form-group">

        </div>

        <div class="col-md-8 form-group">

            <input type="text" id="{{ input-id-two }}" class="form-control">

        </div>
    </fieldset>
</form>

Input groups

Extend form controls by adding text or buttons before, after, or on both sides of any text-based input. Use .input-group with an .input-group-addon to prepend or append elements to a form <input> element.

Cross-browser compatibility

Avoid using <select> elements here as they cannot be fully styled in WebKit browsers.

Tooltips & popovers in input groups require special setting

When using tooltips or popovers on elements within an .input-group, you'll have to specify the container option (container: 'body') to avoid unwanted side effects (such as the element growing wider and/or losing its rounded corners when the tooltip or popover is triggered).

Example

@
.00
$ .00 
<div class="input-group">
    <span class="input-group-addon">@</span>
    <input type="text" class="form-control" title="Username" placeholder="Username">
</div>

<div class="input-group">
    <input type="text" class="form-control" title="Decimals" placeholder="Decimals">
    <span class="input-group-addon">.00</span>
</div>

<div class="input-group">
    <span class="input-group-addon">$</span>
    <input type="text" class="form-control" title="Dollars" placeholder="Dollars">
    <span class="input-group-addon">.00</span>
</div>

Accessible input group markup

Take note of the title attribute that is added to each <input> in these examples. Since nesting a proper <label> element won’t work for this component, adding a title in it’s place ensures that the component is compliant according to WCAG 2.0.

Size variations

Add the relative form sizing classes to the .input-group itself and contents within will automatically resize—no need for repeating the form control size classes on each element.

@
@
@
@ 
<div class="input-group input-group-lg">
    <span class="input-group-addon">@</span>
    <input type="text" class="form-control" title="Username" placeholder="Username">
</div>

<div class="input-group">
    <span class="input-group-addon">@</span>
    <input type="text" class="form-control" title="Username" placeholder="Username">
</div>

<div class="input-group input-group-sm">
    <span class="input-group-addon">@</span>
    <input type="text" class="form-control" title="Username" placeholder="Username">
</div>

<div class="input-group input-group-xs">
    <span class="input-group-addon">@</span>
    <input type="text" class="form-control" title="Username" placeholder="Username">
</div>

Checkboxes and radio button addons

Place any checkbox or radio option within an input group’s addon instead of text.

<fieldset class="row">
    <div class="col-md-6">
        <div class="input-group">
            <span class="input-group-addon">
                <input type="checkbox" aria-controls="{{ input-id-one }}">
            </span>
            <input type="text" id="{{ input-id-one }}"
                   title="Input description"
                   class="form-control">
        </div><!-- /input-group -->
    </div><!-- /.col-md-6 -->
    <div class="col-md-6">
        <div class="input-group">
            <span class="input-group-addon">
                <input type="radio" aria-controls="{{ input-id-two }}">
            </span>
            <input type="text" id="{{ input-id-two }}"
                   title="Input description"
                   class="form-control">
        </div><!-- /input-group -->
    </div><!-- /.col-md-6 -->
</fieldset><!-- /.row -->

Accessible input group checkbox / radio markup

Take note of the aria-controls attribute that is added to each <input type="checkbox"> and <input type="radio"> in these examples. This helps ensure that the component is compliant according to WCAG 2.0.

Button addons

Buttons in input groups are a bit different and require one extra level of nesting. Instead of .input-group-addon, you'll need to use .input-group-btn to wrap the buttons. This is required due to default browser styles that cannot be overridden.

<fieldset class="row">
    <div class="col-md-6">
        <div class="input-group">
            <span class="input-group-btn">
                <button type="button" class="btn"
                        aria-controls="{{ input-id-one }}">
                    Go!
                </button>
            </span>
            <input type="text" id="{{ input-id-one }}"
                   title="Input description"
                   class="form-control">
        </div><!-- /input-group -->
    </div><!-- /.col-md-6 -->
    <div class="col-md-6">
        <div class="input-group">
            <input type="text" id="{{ input-id-two }}"
                   title="Input description"
                   class="form-control">
            <span class="input-group-btn">
                <button type="button" class="btn"
                        aria-controls="{{ input-id-two }}">
                    Go!
                </button>
            </span>
        </div><!-- /input-group -->
    </div><!-- /.col-md-6 -->
</fieldset>

Accessible input group button markup

Take note of the aria-controls attribute that is added to each <button> in these examples. This helps ensure that the component is compliant according to WCAG 2.0.

Buttons

Button styles can be applied to anything with the .btn class applied.

Button options

Use any of the available button classes to quickly create a styled button.

Relative positioning required

If you need to use absolute positioning on a .btn for your layout, wrap it in a .btn-group (or some other block element), and apply the positioning to the wrapper - not to the .btn itself.

Why? In order to achieve the “punchable” style on a button’s :active state, we use a relative position of top: 1px.

<!-- Standard gray button with gradient -->
<button type="button" class="btn btn-default">Default</button>

<!-- Provides extra visual weight and identifies the primary action in a set of buttons -->
<button type="button" class="btn btn-primary">Primary</button>

<!-- Indicates a successful or positive action -->
<button type="button" class="btn btn-success">Success</button>

<!-- Contextual button for informational alert messages -->
<button type="button" class="btn btn-alt">Alternate</button>

<!-- Indicates caution should be taken with this action -->
<button type="button" class="btn btn-warning">Warning</button>

<!-- Indicates a dangerous or potentially negative action -->
<button type="button" class="btn btn-error">Error</button>

<!-- Deemphasize a button by making it look like a link while maintaining button behavior -->
<button type="button" class="btn btn-link">Link</button>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-button:{variation}  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Size variations

Fancy larger or smaller buttons? Add .btn-lg, .btn-sm, or .btn-xs for additional sizes.

Example Font Size Vertical Padding Horizontal Padding Height 
<button type="button" class="btn btn-lg">Large button</button>
<button type="button" class="btn">Default button</button>
<button type="button" class="btn btn-sm">Small button</button>
<button type="button" class="btn btn-xs">Xsmall button</button>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-button:{size}:{variation}  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Block variation

Create block level buttons—those that span the full width of a parent— by adding .btn-block.

<button type="button" class="btn btn-lg btn-block btn-alt">Block level button</button>
<button type="button" class="btn btn-lg btn-block">Block level button</button>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-button:block:{variation}  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Callout variation

When you want a single button on a page to have a more polished / important appearance, use .btn-callout to add our Gibson web-font styling to it. (Only available on regular / large buttons)

<button type="button" class="btn btn-lg btn-alt btn-callout">Large callout</button>
<button type="button" class="btn btn-callout">Default callout</button>

Button states

Use the CSS classes / HTML attributes shown below to make buttons indicate a specific application or task state.

Active state

Buttons will appear pressed (with a darker background, darker border, and offset position) when active. This is done via the CSS :active pseudo-class, or by adding the .active CSS class. The use of the .active CSS class is commonly used if you need to programatically activate a button, or to create entire button-group toggle controls.

Use of our JS buttons plugin is recommended

We recommend toggling the state of a button using our buttons plugin.

<button type="button" class="btn btn-lg btn-alt active">Active Button</button>

Disabled state

Make buttons look unclickable by fading them back .

Cross-browser compatibility

If you add the disabled attribute to a <button>, Internet Explorer 9 and below will render text gray with a nasty text-shadow that we cannot fix.

Link functionality of <a> not impacted

The .disabled class will only change the appearance of <a class="btn"> buttons, not their functionality. Either use custom JS to disable links containing the disabled CSS class, or use <button> elems with proper disabled attributes instead (recommended).

Make disabled buttons accessible

If you choose to use the .disabled class instead of the recommended disabled attribute, add aria-disabled="true" to the .disabled element to ensure WCAG 2.0 compliance.

Button element

Add the disabled attribute to <button> buttons.

<button type="button" class="btn btn-default" disabled>Default</button>
<button type="button" class="btn btn-primary" disabled>Primary</button>
<button type="button" class="btn btn-alt" disabled>Alternate</button>
<button type="button" class="btn btn-success" disabled>Success</button>
<button type="button" class="btn btn-warning" disabled>Warning</button>
<button type="button" class="btn btn-error" disabled>Error</button>
<button type="button" class="btn btn-link" disabled>Link</button>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-button:disabled  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Anchor element

Add the .disabled class to <a> buttons.

Default Primary Alternate Success Warning Error Link 

<a href="#" class="btn btn-default disabled" role="button">Default</a>
<a href="#" class="btn btn-primary disabled" role="button">Primary</a>
<a href="#" class="btn btn-alt disabled" role="button">Alternate</a>
<a href="#" class="btn btn-success disabled" role="button">Success</a>
<a href="#" class="btn btn-warning disabled" role="button">Warning</a>
<a href="#" class="btn btn-error disabled" role="button">Error</a>
<a href="#" class="btn btn-link disabled" role="button">Link</a>

Use multiple tags

Use the button classes on an <a>, <button>, <div role="button">, or <input> element.

Link
Div
<!-- RECOMMENDED -->
<a href="#" role="button" class="btn">Link</a>
<button type="button" class="btn">Button</button>
<div role="button" class="btn">Div</div>

<!-- NOT RECOMMENDED, BUT AVAILABLE -->
<input type="button" class="btn" value="Input">
<input type="submit" class="btn" value="Submit">

Cross-browser rendering

As a best practice, we highly recommend using the <button> element whenever possible to ensure matching cross-browser rendering.

Among other things, there’s a Firefox bug that prevents us from setting the line-height of <input>-based buttons, causing them to not exactly match the height of other buttons in Firefox.

Images

Add classes to an <img> element to easily style images in any project.

Cross-browser compatibility

Keep in mind that MSIE 8 and below lacks support for rounded corners.

Responsive images

Looking for how to make images more responsive? Check out the responsive images section up top.

<img src="..." alt="..." class="img-rounded">
<img src="..." alt="..." class="img-circle">
<img src="..." alt="..." class="img-thumbnail">
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-image  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Usage examples

Add the appropriate class to any inline element. All icon classes are prefixed with icon- for easy styling. To use, place the following code just about anywhere:

  • Use them in buttons, button groups for a toolbar, navigation, or prepended form inputs.
  • Want to change the icon color? Just change the color of the parent element.
  • When using beside strings of text, as in buttons or nav links, be sure to leave a space after the icon for proper spacing.
<i class="icon icon-comment"></i>

MSIE 7 Icon Support

If your app needs to support MSIE 7, be sure that you’ve included wdesk_ie7.css as specified in our getting started docs.

Two color icons

Some of our icons have an optional second color (See: Two Color Set above). To add the second color, add .icon-two-color to the icon element.

Not Supported in MSIE 7

Two color icons are unsupported in MSIE 7. Anywhere you specify .icon-two-color, a single color icon will appear in it’s place.

<i class="icon icon-file-msexcel icon-two-color"></i>
<i class="icon icon-file-mspowerpoint icon-two-color"></i>
<i class="icon icon-file-msword icon-two-color"></i>
<i class="icon icon-file-pdf icon-two-color"></i>
<i class="icon icon-image icon-two-color"></i>

Single color icons

For WFML Doctype icons, a single color is used to denote their “type”. Add .icon-color to any of the file types from our Doctypes icon set shown below to get the correct color.






<!-- FIRST ROW -->
<i class="icon icon-file icon-color"></i>
<i class="icon icon-file-presentation icon-color"></i>
<i class="icon icon-file-workbook icon-color"></i>
<i class="icon icon-file-datacollections icon-color"></i>
<i class="icon icon-file-certification icon-color"></i>

More single color icon options

Since Web Skin icons are ultimately text on the page, you can change their color simply by adding any of the text color utility classes to the icon element itself.






<!-- FIRST ROW -->
<i class="icon icon-filter-outlined text-muted"></i>
<i class="icon icon-filter text-blue"></i>
<i class="icon icon-checkmark-sign-outline text-success"></i>
<i class="icon icon-warning-sign text-warning"></i>
<i class="icon icon-close-sign-outline text-error"></i>

Fancy larger or smaller icons? Add any of the size variation classes shown below for additional sizes.

  • Base 16
  • Base 24

Icons in buttons

Icons nested within buttons will automatically inherit the correct size, color and vertical alignment based on the size of the button.

<button type="button" class="btn btn-lg">
    <i class="icon icon-comment"></i>
    Large btn
</button>
<button type="button" class="btn">
    <i class="icon icon-comment"></i>
    Default btn
</button>
<button type="button" class="btn btn-sm">
    <i class="icon icon-comment"></i>
    Small btn
</button>
<button type="button" class="btn btn-xs">
    <i class="icon icon-comment"></i>
    Xsmall btn
</button>

Horizontal icon alignment in buttons

The examples above show icons to the left of text within buttons. If you want an icon to appear to the right of the text in a button, there are two ways to do this: Floating the icon right using the .pull-right CSS class, or changing the nesting order of the icon itself and adding the .icon-align-right CSS class.

<!-- No change to DOM nesting order (via float) -->
<button type="button" class="btn btn-default">
    <i class="icon icon-lock pull-right"></i>
    Icon Floated Right
</button>
<!-- Actual DOM nesting order must be altered -->
<button type="button" class="btn btn-default">
    Icon Nested Right
    <i class="icon icon-lock icon-align-right"></i>
</button>

Button group in a button toolbar

<div class="btn-toolbar">
    <div class="btn-group">
        <button type="button" class="btn no-text">
            <i class="icon icon-arrow-up"></i>
        </button>
        <button type="button" class="btn no-text">
            <i class="icon icon-arrow-down"></i>
        </button>
        <button type="button" class="btn no-text">
            <i class="icon icon-arrow-left"></i>
        </button>
        <button type="button" class="btn no-text">
            <i class="icon icon-arrow-right"></i>
        </button>
    </div>
</div>

Centering icons in buttons

In the button toolbar example above, icons are shown within buttons with no accompanying text. In order to reset the default horizontal margin applied to icons within buttons, add the .no-text CSS helper class to the button.

Size variant class matching

  • 2012 10-K in 2012 
<!-- DEFAULT -->
<ul role="menu" class="dropdown-menu">
    <li role="presentation">
        <a class="hitarea" href="#" tabindex="-1">
            <i class="icon icon-file-project"></i> ...
        </a>
    </li>

    <li role="presentation">

        </a>
    </li>

<!-- LARGE -->

        </a>
    </li>
</ul>

Form controls with icons

<div class="form-group">
    <label class="col-md-3 control-label" for="inputIcon">Email address:</label>
    <div class="col-md-9">
        <div class="input-group">

        </div>
    </div>
</div>

Helper classes

Web Skin comes with some global, reusable CSS classes that make building Wdesk app UI easier.

.hide / .show

Use these core visiblity classes to control the visibility of elements on your page. Any element with class show will appear - even if the hide class is also present.

You can’t see me.

<div class="well">
    <p class="hide">You can&rsquo;t see me.</p>
    <p class="hide show">Lorem ipsum...</p>
</div>

Scroll utilities

Use these utility classes to control the overflow of content in your components.

.scroll-x

If the contents of an element with this class exceeds the width of the element, a horizontal scrollbar appears.

.scroll-x-force

An element with this class always displays a horizontal scrollbar.

.scroll-y

If the contents of an element with this class exceeds the height of the element, a vertical scrollbar appears.

.scroll-y-force

An element with this class always displays a vertical scrollbar.

.scroll

If the contents of an element with this class exceeds the width or height of the element, a scrollbar appears in the direction of the aforementioned overflow.

.scroll-force

An element with this class always displays a vertical and horizontal scrollbar.

Carets

Use these handy symbols to provide a visual cue for a directional user-interaction in any direction, most commonly used in buttons that trigger dropdown menus.

Default Size

Down (default)
Up
Right
Left

Small Size

Down (default)
Up
Right
Left
<i aria-hidden="true" class="caret"></i>
<i aria-hidden="true" class="caret caret-up"></i>
<i aria-hidden="true" class="caret caret-right"></i>
<i aria-hidden="true" class="caret caret-left"></i>
<!-- Small Variation -->
<i aria-hidden="true" class="caret caret-sm"></i>
<i aria-hidden="true" class="caret caret-sm caret-up"></i>
<i aria-hidden="true" class="caret caret-sm caret-right"></i>
<i aria-hidden="true" class="caret caret-sm caret-left"></i>

Make carets accessible

Since carets don’t have any semantic meaning without being able to visually observe the triangular shape of the element, be sure to add a aria-hidden="true" to every .caret element to ensure WCAG 2.0 compliance.

No text

When Icons or Carets are used within certain containers, they have some default horizontal margin applied to provide appropriate spacing from the text within the container.

If you need to use an Icon or Caret within one of the containers listed below by itself, add the no-text CSS helper class to container to reset the horizontal margin.

This table displays the various situations that result in a .icon or .caret element having default horizontal margins that can be reset by utilizing the .no-text CSS helper class.

  1. The first column describes the context of the examples in the proceeding columns.
  2. The second column shows an example of the icon/caret utilizing the default margin to provide separation from the text.
  3. The third column shows an example of the icon/caret in a container that has no text, but still has the default horizontal margin applied.
  4. The fourth column shows an example of the situation displayed in the third column with the .no-text CSS helper class applied, which ensures that the icon/caret is horizontally centered within its container.
Context With Text W/out Text Using .no-text
Button + Icon 
<button type="button" class="btn btn-default no-text">
    <i class="icon icon-lock"></i>
</button>
Dropdown Button + Caret
  • Books
  • Certifications

  • Books
  • Certifications
  • Section 16
  • Books
  • Certifications
  • Section 16 
<button type="button" class="btn btn-default dropdown-toggle no-text">
    <i class="caret" aria-hidden="true"></i>
</button>

Make icon-only links accessible

Be sure to add some descriptive text to any button that only has an icon visible using the .sr-only accessibility helper class to ensure WCAG 2.0 compliance.

“Close” / “Clear” icon

Use the generic close icon for dismissing dialogs like modals and alerts, or clearing the contents of a form input.

Dismissing a dialog

This example is taken from our modal dialog specification.

Dialog title…

Messenger bag forage retro pork belly 3 wolf moon Godard. Gluten-free literally forage, retro normcore fanny pack fingerstache. Bitters semiotics blog, readymade butcher iPhone shabby chic crucifix tofu yr skateboard Brooklyn. Typewriter tofu PBR irony. Street art gluten-free chambray art party VHS. Mlkshk Blue Bottle pug freegan. Meggings squid leggings, iPhone pop-up skateboard shabby chic lo-fi.

<button type="button" class="close" data-dismiss="{{ component.type }}"
        title="Close {{ component.type }}">
    <i aria-hidden="true">&times;</i>
    <i class="sr-only">Close {{ component.type }}</i>
</button>

Clearing form input value

The visual pattern for the “Close” icon when used within a form field is slightly different. The hover state invokes a red color to indicate to the user that they are about to remove potentially un-commited data from a form.

This example is taken from our search input specification.

<button type="button" class="btn clear-search">
    <i aria-hidden="true">&times;</i>
    <i class="sr-only">Clear Search</i>
</button>

Make “close” icon links accessible

Be sure to add some descriptive text to any .close button using the .sr-only accessibility helper class to ensure WCAG 2.0 compliance.

.pull-left

Float an element left

<div class="pull-left">...</div>
.pull-left {
    float: left;
}

.pull-right

Float an element right

<div class="pull-right">...</div>
.pull-right {
    float: right;
}

.clearfix

Clear the float on any element. Utilizes the micro clearfix as popularized by Nicolas Gallagher.

<div class="element">...</div>
// Mixin
@mixin clearfix {
    &:before,
    &:after {
        content: " ";
        display: table;
    }
    &:after {
        clear: both;
    }
}

// Usage
.element {
    @include clearfix;
}

Screen reader and keyboard navigation content

Hide an element to all users except screen readers with .sr-only.

Necessary for following accessibility best practices. Can also be used as a Sass mixin.

<button type="button" class="close">
    <i aria-hidden="true">&times;</i>
    <i class="sr-only">Close</i>
</button>
// Usage as a Sass Mixin
.your-custom-class {
  @include sr-only;
}

Combine .sr-only with .sr-only-focusable to show the element again when it’s focused (e.g. by a keyboard-only user). Can also be used as a Sass mixin.

<a class="sr-only sr-only-focusable" href="#content">Skip to main content</a>
// Usage as a Sass Mixin
.skip-navigation {
  @include sr-only;
  @include sr-only-focusable;
}

Responsive utilities

For faster mobile-first development, use these utility classes for showing and hiding content by device via CSS media queries.

Available classes

Try to use these on a limited basis and avoid creating entirely different versions of the same site. Instead, use them to complement each device’s presentation.

Usage with inline elements

When using these responsive visibility classes on elements that should be display: inline; when visible, be sure to add the .inline CSS class.

<p>Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, <span class="hidden-xs inline">consectetur adipisicing elit</span>, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.</p>
